talking about section 12g of the
Securities Exchange Act and I was
wondering if you could give us a brief
rundown of what that is sure section 12g
of the Exchange Act was enacted to
ensure that companies who go over a
certain threshold with their shareholder
base are required to register with the
SEC the base that we're talking about is
500 shareholders and assets of 10
million dollars once that happens
companies have to file reports with the
SEC so their shareholders know what's
happening with the company in terms of
financial results business plans and
other items what was the idea behind
that why would they why would they
require that the basic idea is investor
protection the Congress did not want a
number of investors say a thousand two
thousand investors to have purchased
shares in the company while not having
the benefit of sec registration there's
a lot of benefits that investors get
when a company registers with the SEC
probably the most important of which are
audited financial statements and ongoing
disclosure so Congress wanted to ensure
investors in companies that were widely
held received all the benefits of SEC
protection so why would a company not
want to hit that 500 threshold there's a
number of reasons why companies wouldn't
want to hit the 500 shareholder
threshold one of the most important
being costs it's very expensive to have
a company registered with the SEC
currently on average studies show
companies spend about five million
dollars a year on legal fees and
accounting fees just to be a publicly
traded company on top of that there's
staff time and other costs but probably
most importantly is that the companies
lose control of their shareholder base
there's room for shareholder activism
more shareholder input into decisions
and very often founders of companies
don't want to have to be subjected to
that type of scrutiny and want to keep
more control for themselves in counting
these 500 shareholders it seems like
Goldman special purpose vehicle will be
counted as just one though it could have
a thousand investors within it it does
that in some ways circumvent the law or
how does the law look at
like that that's the big question right
now Goldman's vehicle is designed to

though it has a number of different

closely scrutinizing this deal because
if Goldman set up this company
specifically to invest in facebook it
starts to sound like especially to the

circumvent the 500 shareholder
requirement and we're really in some new
territory here so there's never been a
case where you've had an individual fund
investing in a private company that is
that consists of multiple investors yeah
essentially here what makes it unique
with Facebook is essentially that this
fund is being formed specifically to
invest in facebook we have other
examples of funds particularly venture
